title: Which recording artists refuse to use autotune? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t know about refusing, but there are plenty of artists that simply wouldn’t ever need to use autotune. I once stood and watched Lady Gaga while she sang some a capella stuff for a fan and have them a few vocal tips … she wouldn’t even need amplification in some venues, let alone autotune. I was about 20ft away but, in addition to being perfectly on pitch, the power and just sheer volume of air she can move when she sings is insane. There are plenty of opera and musical theater singers out there that are still another order of magnitude above any pop singer that’s ever been on the Billboard charts in terms of vocal skill and intonation. I’ve heard that smaller theatres sometimes use live autotune for chorus lines and such nowadays, which is disappointing to hear about but I’ve never seen/heard direct evidence of this. I would generally say any singer who has years of training and has put in lots of hours of practice time over those years wouldn’t ever need to rely on autotune — unless it was to use it as an effect. Billie Eilish and her brother, Finneas, don’t use autotune for pitch correction — but similarly, they’ve been immersed in music since they were toddlers and they each have quite a few years of choir singing/training on top of that, so I can’t see them ever needing to use those sorts of filters. This Rolling Stone video shows the lengths they went to just for the vocals on Billie’s hit, “Bad Guy”.

I would guess that autotune is used in the studio a lot more than the public realizes.  However, it's not something that an artist is going to freely admit to. I disagree with comparing it to steroids in baseball.  It's cheating in baseball because baseball has rules.  There's no official rule book for making music.  Does it really matter if a singer makes a "perfect" compilation of 50 takes, or just does two and uses some autotune? I agree that the ability to sing in perfect pitch is a talent, but I don't believe in putting down those who choose to use autotune.  Just remember that if you want to be anti-autotune, for consistency in your beliefs, you should also be against fretted instruments.  Clearly, playing a fretless guitar requires more talent than the common fretted one. For me, what matters is what the finished product sounds like.
